title: Admit One: Coming events in lohud
text:
Admit One: Coming events in lohud Michelle Almonte , malmonte@lohud.com 12:57 p.m. EDT October 16, 2015 Buy Photo The mussels at Slyce in Ardsley, photographed July 30, 2015. Slyce restaurant is an updated version of Ardsley Pizza with artisan pies, craft beers and wine added to the menu. (Photo: Tania Savayan/The Journal News) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
1. Fall Hudson Valley Restaurant Week 
Loosen a notch on your belt because Hudson Valley Restaurant Week returns for fall season starting Nov. 2. For two weeks (event ends on Nov. 15), diners can enjoy dishes from more than 100 Westchester County restaurants. Restaurant Week features prix fixe, three-course dinners for $29.95 and lunches for $20.95. Participating venues include Crabtree’s Kittle House and X2O Xaviars on the Hudson. For more information, visit www.hudsonvalleyrestaurantweek.com 
2. Friends of Music Concerts 
Friends of Music Concerts presents a recital by the world-renowned pianist Yefim Bronfman on Nov. 7, as part of its 62nd season. Additional chamber music performances include: The Montrose Trio on Oct. 24; Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, April 16; pianist Yun-Chin Zhou, April 30; the Pacifica Quartet, May 14. For adults, subscriptions for the six-concert series are $120; tickets to individual concerts are $30. Students 18 years and younger are admitted free. Subscription and single-ticket orders can be mailed with a check to Friends of Music Concerts, P.O. Box 675, Millwood, NY 10546. All concerts will be held at 8 p.m. in Sleepy Hollow High School’s Kusel Auditorium, 210 North Broadway. 914-861-5080. friendsofmusicconcerts.org 
Yefim Bronfman (Photo: Dario Acosta) 
3. Westchester's Winter Wonderland 
Kensico Dam Plaza is transformed into a world of fantasy for Westchester’s Winter Wonderland, with over 2 million lights, holiday music, food, shopping, and attractions including sleigh rides, ice skating and visits with Santa. Opening Nov. 27, this year’s attraction boasts new features including: a bigger ice skating rink where visitors can meet New York Rangers alumni and receive fun giveaways, an amusement ride, an expanded Shopping Village of artisan crafts and gifts, as well as a new heated entertainment tent with holiday programming. Avoid long lines upon arrival by ordering tickets online at www.wwinterwonderland.com . 1 Bronx River Parkway, Valhalla. Buy Photo 
Friends and families attend the Westchester Winter Wonderland lighting ceremony at Kensico Dam Plaza, Nov. 29, 2014 in Valhalla. In addition to watching the light show that used over 2.5 million LED lights, families enjoyed ice skating, sleigh rides, the Himalaya ride and shopping at boutique vendors. (Photo: , Tania Savayan/The Journal News) 
4. Nyack Halloween Parade 
Though popular (second in the tri-state only to Greenwich Village’s), families won’t have to worry about admission at the Nyack Halloween Parade. Expect to see thousands of spectators, floats and costumes at the annual parade. The festivities kick off with live music in Main Street Parking Lot before the parade steps off from Memorial Park. All are welcome to march and register for prizes for the best costumes and floats. This year’s event is on Oct. 24. For more information, contact 845-353-2221 or nyackchamber.org . Buy Photo 
Thousands of spectators enjoyed the festivities at the 27th annual Nyack Halloween Parade in Nyack, NY on October 25, 2014 (Photo: , Kurt Beebe for The Journal News) 
5. Westchester Knicks 
The Westchester Knicks will tip off its second season with a game against the Maine Red Claws on Nov. 12. The match-up highlights a 24-home-game schedule. Season tickets for the 2015-16 season are on sale now and start at $10 per game. 7 p.m. For more information including discounts on tickets, visit WestchesterKnicks.com or call 914-559-6889. Westchester County Center, 198 Central Ave., White Plains. Buy Photo 
The Westchester Knicks played the Canton Charge in an NBA D-League game at the Westchester County Center in White Plains March 24, 2015. (Photo: Seth Harrison/The Journal News) 
6. Westchester Philharmonic 
Don’t miss Westchester Philharmonic’s 33rd season opening concert on Sunday. Principal Conductor Jaime Laredo leads the orchestra in a performance of Christopher Theofanidis’s “Dreamtime Ancestors,” a work co-commissioned by 48 regional orchestras throughout the country for sequential performances that will last through 2017. 3 p.m. Tickets: $30-$98. To purchase, buy online or call 914-682-3707, ext. 10. Performances will take place in The Concert Hall at The Performing Arts Center, Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase.For the complete season schedule, visit www.westchesterphil.org . 
7. Walk for Peace OUTside Campus 
Runners and walkers can participate in the 11th annual 5K Lindsey Run/Walk, organized by PEACE OUTside campus and the Lindsey M. Bonistall Foundation at Purchase College, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase. Oct. 25. Lindsey Bonistall was a University of Delaware sophomore from White Plains who was murdered in her off-campus apartment in Delaware in 2005. For more information about PEACE OUTside Campus, visit www.peaceoutside 
8. Garland Jeffreys Band 
Garland Jeffreys and his band strut their musical stuff at the next Words & Music concert series Oct. 23. Jeffreys produced his newest album “Truth Serum” with production support by James Maddock and Larry Campbell. Tickets are $30 and can be purchased at budarztheater.brownpapertickets.com . 8 p.m. Ossining Public Library, 53 Croton Ave. 
Get Listed 
To list an event on lohud.com and in The Journal News, go to events.lohud.com and follow the prompt to “Add Event.” You will need to create your own personal Eventful account which allows you to add your event information, photos, even links. For questions, please contact Michelle Almonte, malmonte@lohud.com. 1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://lohud.us/1LxWOUR MORE STORIES
